We currently run JUnit with 1000 unittests with no outofMemory exceptions
being thrown.

There's no limit within JUnit that could cause your problem. I suspect that
there is some form of resource hogging occurring within your code (either
test code, production code, or both) that is the real cause of the problem.

The setUp() & tearDown() methods that JUnit calls before & after each
testcase (method) is called, should be used where necessary to release
resources. This will allow the GarbageCollector to free memory as needed,
without you having to change the JVM's heap size.

HTH

Andrew
